paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: The paper discusses the role of TTR variants in familial amyloidotic polyneuropathy (FAP), specifically focusing on the V30M mutation. It provides insights into penetrance data, patient demographics, and the clinical significance of the TTR gene.

patients.demographics: three males and two females, aged between 40 and 60 years old

individual_records.evidence_sentence: Twenty milliliters of blood samples from n = 5 V30M FAP patients (three males and two females), aged between 40 and 60 years old.
Twenty milliliters of blood samples from n = 5 V30M FAP patients (three males and two females), aged between 40 and 60 years old.

Sural nerve biopsies from asymptomatic individuals had no amyloid deposition.
Sural nerve biopsies from asymptomatic individuals had no amyloid deposition.

functional_data.summary: The V30M mutation in TTR is associated with the development of familial amyloidotic polyneuropathy, leading to protein deposition in peripheral nerves.

variants.segregation_data: The V30M variant segregates with disease in families, as evidenced by the presence of affected individuals among carriers.
variants.additional_notes: The study highlights the importance of TTR variants in the pathogenesis of FAP and the role of inflammation in disease progression.
key_quotes: Sural nerve biopsies from asymptomatic individuals had no amyloid deposition.
Twenty milliliters of blood samples from n = 5 V30M FAP patients (three males and two females), aged between 40 and 60 years old.

extraction_metadata.notes: The extraction was straightforward as the paper provided clear information regarding the TTR variant.
